caption:
This photograph features a close-up view of fungus growth, primarily presenting what appears to be clusters of slime mold or a similar type of fungi. The image shows numerous slim, stalk-like structures topped with bulbous, lighter-colored heads that appear almost white or pale pink in color. These structures are densely packed in several clusters, spreading across the image amidst a background that suggests a natural, possibly damp environment.

The overall setting is dark and shadowy, with the illuminated fungi creating a contrasting, vivid display against the subdued hues of their surroundings. Besides the fungal formations, details of the undergrowth, possibly decaying wood or leaf litter, are scattered throughout the frame, contributing to a sense of organic clutter and texture. This setting is typical for fungal and mold growth as they often thrive in moist, organic-rich environments.

The lighting used in the photograph highlights the texture and form of the fungi, casting small shadows and creating a sense of depth and detail, emphasizing their slender stalks and rounded heads. The photo captures the intricate, and somewhat eerie, beauty of fungal life in a natural habitat, conveying a microscopic world that might usually go unnoticed.
title: Close-up lichen growing on an old stump. Taken on Green Mountain, Washington, near Seattle, Washington. From the Environmental Protection Agency's Project DOCUMERICA collection, "In Praise of Forests". For additional images see fiche #s 209, 210, 211, 212, and 213. ENTHEOS. July, 1974.
